channel.title: Enumeration on TLDRBins
channel.description: Recent content in Enumeration on TLDRBins

item.title: Azure Enum
item.description:
Recon

1. Authenticate

roadrecon auth -u '<USER>' -p '<PASSWORD>'

┌──(venv)─(kali㉿kali)-[~]
└─$ roadrecon auth -u 'apple.seed@example.com' -p 'Test1234'
Tokens were written to .roadtools_auth

2. Info Gathering

roadrecon gather

┌──(venv)─(kali㉿kali)-[~]
└─$ roadrecon gather                                                       
Starting data gathering phase 1 of 2 (collecting objects)
Starting data gathering phase 2 of 2 (collecting properties and relationships)
ROADrecon gather executed in 12.27 seconds and issued 1152 HTTP requests.

3. Explore the Data

roadrecon gui

┌──(venv)─(kali㉿kali)-[~]
└─$ roadrecon gui   
 * Serving Flask app 'roadtools.roadrecon.server'
 * Debug mode: off
WARNING: This is a development server. Do not use it in a production deployment. Use a production WSGI server instead.
 * Running on http://127.0.0.1:5000
Press CTRL+C to quit

Ref: ROADTools

item.title: Bloodhound
item.description:
Info Collection (From Linux)

# Password
bloodhound-python -d <DOMAIN> -u '<USER>' -p '<PASSWORD>' -dc <DC> -ns <DC_IP> -c all --zip

$ python3 bloodhound.py -d rebound.htb -u oorend -p '1GR8t@$$4u' -dc dc01.rebound.htb -ns 10.10.11.231 -c all --zip 
INFO: Found AD domain: rebound.htb
INFO: Getting TGT for user
INFO: Connecting to LDAP server: dc01.rebound.htb
WARNING: LDAP Authentication is refused because LDAP signing is enabled. Trying to connect over LDAPS instead...
INFO: Found 1 domains

---[SNIP]---

INFO: Found 0 trusts
INFO: Starting computer enumeration with 10 workers
INFO: Querying computer: dc01.rebound.htb
INFO: Done in 00M 50S
INFO: Compressing output into 20240923035110_bloodhound.zip

# NTLM
bloodhound-python -d <DOMAIN> -u '<USER>' --hashes ':<HASH>' -dc <DC> -ns <DC_IP> -c all --zip

# Kerberos
sudo ntpdate -s <DC_IP> && bloodhound-python -u '<USER>' -k -d <DOMAIN> -dc <DC> -ns <DC_IP> -c all --zip -no-pass --use-ldaps

Note: passing '-no-pass' will still ask for password, press enter

item.title: Cloud Enum
item.description:
Cloud Enum

python3 cloud_enum.py -k <KEYWORD>

┌──(venv)─(kali㉿kali)-[~/Desktop]
└─$ python3 cloud_enum.py -k example.com

##########################
        cloud_enum
   github.com/initstring
##########################


Keywords:    example.com
Mutations:   /home/kali/Desktop/cloud_enum/enum_tools/fuzz.txt
Brute-list:  /home/kali/Desktop/cloud_enum/enum_tools/fuzz.txt

[+] Mutations list imported: 306 items
[+] Mutated results: 1837 items

++++++++++++++++++++++++++
      amazon checks
++++++++++++++++++++++++++

[+] Checking for S3 buckets
  OPEN S3 BUCKET: http://example.com.s3.amazonaws.com/
      FILES:
      ->http://example.com.s3.amazonaws.com/example.com
---[SNIP]---
      ->http://example.com.s3.amazonaws.com/tmp/
      ->http://example.com.s3.amazonaws.com/tmp/abcd1234/
      ->http://example.com.s3.amazonaws.com/tmp/abcd1234/.htaccess
      ->http://example.com.s3.amazonaws.com/tmp/abcd1234/.htpasswd
---[SNIP]---

Ref: cloud_enum

item.title: DNS
item.description:
Enum

dnsenum --dnsserver <NAME_SERVER> -p 0 -s 0 --threads=10 -f /usr/share/seclists/Discovery/DNS/bitquark-subdomains-top100000.txt <DOMAIN>

Zone Transfer

dig +noall +answer @<NAME_SERVER> <DOMAIN> AXFR 

$ dig +noall +answer snoopy.htb axfr @10.10.11.212
snoopy.htb.             86400   IN      SOA     ns1.snoopy.htb. ns2.snoopy.htb. 2022032612 3600 1800 604800 86400
snoopy.htb.             86400   IN      NS      ns1.snoopy.htb.
snoopy.htb.             86400   IN      NS      ns2.snoopy.htb.
mattermost.snoopy.htb.  86400   IN      A       172.18.0.3
mm.snoopy.htb.          86400   IN      A       127.0.0.1
ns1.snoopy.htb.         86400   IN      A       10.0.50.10
ns2.snoopy.htb.         86400   IN      A       10.0.51.10
postgres.snoopy.htb.    86400   IN      A       172.18.0.2
provisions.snoopy.htb.  86400   IN      A       172.18.0.4
www.snoopy.htb.         86400   IN      A       127.0.0.1
snoopy.htb.             86400   IN      SOA     ns1.snoopy.htb. ns2.snoopy.htb. 2022032612 3600 1800 604800 86400

# Spoof source ip
dig +noall +answer @<NAME_SERVER> <DOMAIN> AXFR -b <IP>

Domain Discovery

nslookup -querytype=<TYPE> <DOMAIN>

$ nslookup -querytype=ANY google.com
Server:         192.168.1.1
Address:        192.168.1.1#53

Non-authoritative answer:
Name:   google.com
Address: 142.250.197.174
Name:   google.com
Address: 2404:6800:4005:823::200e
google.com
        origin = ns1.google.com
        mail addr = dns-admin.google.com
        serial = 780174493
        refresh = 900
        retry = 900
        expire = 1800
        minimum = 60
google.com      nameserver = ns3.google.com.
google.com      nameserver = ns1.google.com.
google.com      nameserver = ns2.google.com.
google.com      nameserver = ns4.google.com.

Authoritative answers can be found from:

dig +noall +answer @<NAME_SERVER> <DOMAIN> <TYPE>

$ dig +noall +answer @8.8.8.8 google.com ANY
google.com.             300     IN      A       142.250.196.238
google.com.             300     IN      AAAA    2404:6800:4005:80b::200e
---[SNIP]---

# Concise Output
dig +noall +answer +short @<NAME_SERVER> <DOMAIN> <TYPE>

$ dig +noall +answer @10.10.11.212 +short snoopy.htb any
ns1.snoopy.htb. ns2.snoopy.htb. 2022032612 3600 1800 604800 86400
ns2.snoopy.htb.
ns1.snoopy.htb.


A     - Address record
AAAA  - IPv6 address record
MX    - Mail exchange record
NS    - Name server record
TXT   - Text record
CNAME - Canonical name record
SOA   - Start of Authority record
ANY   - Retrieves all available record types (not always supported)


# Reverse Lookup
dig +noall +answer @<NAME_SERVER> -x <IP>

$ dig +noall +answer @10.10.11.212 -x 10.10.11.212

Update DNS Record

1. Interactive

nsupdate

2. Update DNS Record

server <NAME_SERVER>

# Optional
zone <ZONE>

# Optional: Assign local source address
local <IP>

local 127.20.0.1

# Optional: Delete a record
update delete <DOMAIN>. A

update add <DOMAIN>. <TTL> <TYPE> <IP>

udpate add example.com. 3600 A 192.168.1.1

send

Check DNS Configuration

Get-WmiObject -Namespace "Root\MicrosoftDNS" -Class "MicrosoftDNS_Zone" | Where-Object { $_.ZoneType -eq <ZONE_TYPE> }


0 - Cache Zone
1 - Primary Zone
2 - Secondary Zone
3 - Stub Zone
4 - Forwarder/Conditional Forwarder Zone

Check A Records

(Get-DnsServerZone).ZoneName | ForEach-Object { $zoneName = $_; $aRecords = Get-DnsServerResourceRecord -ZoneName $zoneName -RRType A; if ($aRecords) { $aRecords | Select-Object @{n="ZoneName";e={$zoneName}}, HostName, @{n="IPAddress";e={$_.RecordData.IPv4Address}} } else { [PSCustomObject]@{ZoneName=$zoneName; HostName="No A records found"; IPAddress=""} } }

item.title: Drupal
item.description:
Enum

droopescan scan drupal -u <TARGET>

Ref: droopescan
Note: This can take a long time to run

item.title: Find
item.description:
Locate a File

locate <FILE>

Files of Type 'File'

find . -type f

Find and Open

find / -name <FILE> -exec cat {} \;

SetUID and SetGID Files

find / -type f -user root \( -perm -4000 -o -perm -2000 \) 2>/dev/null -ls

Files Owned by User

find / -user <USER> -ls 2>/dev/null | grep -v -e " \/proc" -e " \/sys"

Files Owned by Group

find / -group <GROUP> 2>/dev/null | grep -v -e ^/proc -e ^/sys

World Writable Files and Directories (Exclude Sticky Bit)

find / -type f,d \( -perm -0002 -a ! -perm /1000 \) 2>/dev/null -ls | grep -v -e " \/proc" -e " \/sys"

Group Writable Files and Directories (Exclude Sticky Bit)

find / -type f,d \( -perm -0020 -a ! -perm /1000 \) 2>/dev/null -ls | grep -v -e " \/proc" -e " \/sys"

Files Created between Time Interval

find / -type f -newermt <YYYY_MM_DD_START> ! -newermt <YYYY_MM_DD_END> -ls 2>/dev/null

find / -type f -newermt 2024-01-01 ! -newermt 2024-12-31 -ls 2>/dev/null

Files with Capabilities

find / -exec getcap {} \; 2>/dev/null

Writable Folders

find . -type d | while read dir; do mkdir ${dir}/test 2>/dev/null && echo "${dir} - directory create OK" && rmdir ${dir}/test; touch ${dir}/test 2>/dev/null && echo "${dir} - file write OK" && rm ${dir}/test; done

Files Not Modified by dpkg (i.e. Modified by Something Else)

find /lib -type f -printf "%M %n %-6u %-6g %6s %TY-%Tm-%Td %TT %TZ %h/%f\n" | sort -k 6,7 | grep -v ".0000000000"

Un-owned Files and Directories

find / -type f,d \( -nouser -o -nogroup \) 2>/dev/null -ls

item.title: Finger Protocol
item.description:
General

# Check logged in users
finger @<TARGET>

# Check valid user
finger <USER>@<TARGET>

Brute Force Usernames

perl finger-user-enum.pl -U /usr/share/seclists/Usernames/Names/names.txt -t <TARGET>

Ref: finger-user-enum

item.title: Git
item.description:
General

# Show status
git status

# Reset the current branch to a previous commit
git reset --hard

# Show information about files
git ls-files --stage

# Show current branch
git branch

# Show commits
git log <BRANCH_NAME> --oneline

# Show diff, a and b are commit hash
# a is the older commit
git diff <A_COMMIT_HASH> <B_COMMIT_HASH>

# Show commit
git show <COMMIT_HASH>

# Clone private repo
git clone http://<USER>:<TOKEN>@<DOMAIN>/<OWNER>/<REPO>.git

# Add file
git add <FILE>

# Commit changes
git commit -am '<MESSAGE>'

# Push changes
git push

Git Tools

git-dumper <TARGET> result/

Ref: git-dumper

item.title: Grep
item.description:
General

grep '<STRING>' <FILE>

Grep from Files Recursively

grep -rni '<STRING>' <PATH>

Grep from Binary

grep -a '<STRING>' <FILE>

Grep Hash from Binary with Perl Regex

grep -aPo '[a-fA-F0-9]{32}' <FILE>

Grep from Binaries Recusively

grep -rHa "<STRING>" <PATH>

Find Unique Char from a File

cat <FILE> | od -cvA none -w1 | sort -bu | tr -d '\n' | tr -d ' '

item.title: Kerberos
item.description:
Users Enum

kerbrute userenum --domain <DOMAIN> --dc <DC> <USERS_FILE>

$ kerbrute userenum --domain absolute.htb --dc dc.absolute.htb usernames.txt

item.title: LDAP
item.description:
Enum

# Get domain base
ldapsearch -x -H ldap://<TARGET> -s base namingcontexts

# Get all from domain
ldapsearch -x -H ldap://<TARGET> -b 'DC=<EXAMPLE>,DC=<COM>'

# Just get a class (e.g. person)
ldapsearch -x -H ldap://<TARGET> -b 'DC=<EXAMPLE>,DC=<COM>' '(objectClass=person)'

# Password
ldapsearch -x -H ldap://<TARGET> -D "CN=<USER>,CN=Users,DC=<EXAMPLE>,DC=<COM>" -w '<PASSWORD>' -b 'DC=<EXAMPLE>,DC=<COM>'

# Fix 'BindSimple: Transport encryption required.'
LDAPTLS_REQCERT=never ldapsearch -x -H ldaps://<TARGET> -D "CN=<USER>,CN=Users,DC=<EXAMPLE>,DC=<COM>" -w '<PASSWORD>' -b 'DC=<EXAMPLE>,DC=<COM>'

# Password
ldapdomaindump -u '<DOMAIN>\<USER>' -p '<PASSWORD>' <TARGET> -o ./ldap

# Using nmap script
sudo nmap -p 389 --script ldap-search <TARGET>

item.title: MongoDB General
item.description:
Connect to Mongo Database

mongosh <TARGET>:27017

$ mongosh 172.17.0.3:27017
Current Mongosh Log ID: 66f2fa2192b07a1eeb856ec6
Connecting to:          mongodb://172.17.0.3:27017/?directConnection=true&appName=mongosh+2.2.12
Using MongoDB:          5.0.6
Using Mongosh:          2.2.12

For mongosh info see: https://docs.mongodb.com/mongodb-shell/

item.title: NetExec (nxc)
item.description:
Basic Commands

# Single user, Single password
nxc <PROTOCOL> <TARGET> -u '<USER>' -p '<PASSWORD>'

# Single user, Single password, Local auth
nxc <PROTOCOL> <TARGET> -u '<USER>' -p '<PASSWORD>' --local-auth

# Single user, Single password (Active Directory)
nxc <PROTOCOL> <TARGET> -u '<USER>' -p '<PASSWORD>' -d <DOMAIN>

# Single user, Multiple passwords
nxc <PROTOCOL> <TARGET> -u '<USER>' -p <PASSWORDS> -d <DOMAIN>

# Multiple users, Single password
nxc <PROTOCOL> <TARGET> -u <USERS> -p '<PASSWORD>' -d <DOMAIN> --continue-on-success

# Multiple users, Multiple passwords
nxc <PROTOCOL> <TARGET> -u <USERS> -p <PASSWORDS> -d <DOMAIN> --continue-on-success

# Match username to corresponding password
nxc <PROTOCOL> <TARGET> -u <USERS> -p <PASSWORDS> --no-bruteforce --continue-on-success

nxc <PROTOCOL> <TARGET> -u '<USER>' -H <HASH>

# With Kerberos, or STATUS_ACCOUNT_RESTRICTION (NTLM disabled)
sudo ntpdate -s <DC_IP> && nxc <PROTOCOL> <TARGET> -u '<USER>' -p '<PASSWORD>' -d <DOMAIN> -k

# With Kerberos ccache, or STATUS_NOT_SUPPORTED (NTLM disabled)
sudo ntpdate -s <DC_IP> && nxc <PROTOCOL> <TARGET> -u '<USER>' -d <DOMAIN> -k --use-kcache

item.title: Nmap
item.description:
Host Discovery

Ping Scan

nmap -sn <TARGET>

$ nmap -sn 192.168.100.1           
Starting Nmap 7.95 ( https://nmap.org ) at 2025-07-17 11:25 UTC
Nmap scan report for 192.168.100.1
Host is up (0.41s latency).
Nmap done: 1 IP address (1 host up) scanned in 1.35 seconds

Scan Techniques (Bypass Network Filtering)

TCP SYN to Listed Ports

nmap -sn -PS<PORT_LIST> <TARGET>

$ nmap -sn -PS53,80,443 192.168.100.1
Starting Nmap 7.95 ( https://nmap.org ) at 2025-07-17 11:25 UTC
Nmap scan report for 192.168.100.1
Host is up (0.40s latency).
Nmap done: 1 IP address (1 host up) scanned in 1.37 seconds

TCP ACK to Listed Ports

nmap -sn -PA<PORT_LIST> <TARGET>

$ nmap -sn -PA53,80,443 192.168.100.1
Starting Nmap 7.95 ( https://nmap.org ) at 2025-07-17 11:25 UTC
Nmap scan report for 192.168.100.1
Host is up (0.44s latency).
Nmap done: 1 IP address (1 host up) scanned in 0.89 seconds

UDP to Listed Ports

nmap -sn -PU<PORT_LIST> <TARGET>

$ nmap -sn -PU53,80,443 192.168.100.1
Starting Nmap 7.95 ( https://nmap.org ) at 2025-07-17 11:25 UTC
Nmap scan report for 192.168.100.1
Host is up (0.40s latency).
Nmap done: 1 IP address (1 host up) scanned in 0.89 seconds

Spoofing Source Port

nmap -g <FAKE_PORT> <TARGET>

$ nmap -g 80 192.168.100.1
Starting Nmap 7.95 ( https://nmap.org ) at 2025-07-17 11:25 UTC
Nmap scan report for 192.168.100.1
Host is up (0.73s latency).
Not shown: 998 closed tcp ports (reset)
PORT   STATE SERVICE
22/tcp open  ssh
80/tcp open  http

Nmap done: 1 IP address (1 host up) scanned in 6.16 seconds

Spoofing IP Address

nmap -S <FAKE_IP> -e <INTERFACE> -Pn <TARGET>

$ nmap -S 192.168.101.1 -e tun0 -Pn 192.168.100.1
Starting Nmap 7.95 ( https://nmap.org ) at 2025-07-17 11:43 UTC
Nmap scan report for 192.168.100.1

Not shown: 998 closed tcp ports (reset)
PORT   STATE SERVICE
22/tcp open  ssh
80/tcp open  http

Nmap done: 1 IP address (1 host up) scanned in 14.78 seconds

Fragmentation

nmap -f <TARGET>

$ nmap -f 192.168.100.1
Starting Nmap 7.95 ( https://nmap.org ) at 2025-07-17 11:42 UTC
Nmap scan report for 192.168.100.1
Host is up (0.053s latency).
Not shown: 998 closed tcp ports (reset)
PORT   STATE SERVICE
22/tcp open  ssh
80/tcp open  http

Nmap done: 1 IP address (1 host up) scanned in 2.24 seconds

OS Fingerprinting (Active)

nmap -O --fuzzy <TARGET>

$ nmap -O --fuzzy 10.129.234.50                               
Starting Nmap 7.95 ( https://nmap.org ) at 2025-07-17 17:00 UTC

Aggressive OS guesses: Microsoft Windows 10 1703 or Windows 11 21H2 (97%), Microsoft Windows Server 2016 or Server 2019 (97%), Microsoft Windows Server 2022 (96%), Windows Server 2019 (95%), Microsoft Windows Server 2012 or 2012 R2 (94%), Microsoft Windows 10 1703 (93%), Windows Server 2022 (93%), Microsoft Windows 10 1511 (93%), Microsoft Windows Server 2012 (93%), Microsoft Windows Server 2016 (93%)
No exact OS matches for host (If you know what OS is running on it, see https://nmap.org/submit/ ).
TCP/IP fingerprint:

OS:O6=M552ST11)WIN(W1=FFFF%W2=FFFF%W3=FFFF%W4=FFFF%W5=FFFF%W6=FFDC)ECN(R=Y%
OS:DF=Y%T=80%W=FFFF%O=M552NW8NNS%CC=Y%Q=)T1(R=Y%DF=Y%T=80%S=O%A=S+%F=AS%RD=
OS:0%Q=)T2(R=Y%DF=Y%T=80%W=0%S=Z%A=S%F=AR%O=%RD=0%Q=)T3(R=Y%DF=Y%T=80%W=0%S
OS:=Z%A=O%F=AR%O=%RD=0%Q=)T4(R=Y%DF=Y%T=80%W=0%S=A%A=O%F=R%O=%RD=0%Q=)T5(R=
OS:Y%DF=Y%T=80%W=0%S=Z%A=S+%F=AR%O=%RD=0%Q=)T6(R=Y%DF=Y%T=80%W=0%S=A%A=O%F=
OS:R%O=%RD=0%Q=)T7(R=Y%DF=Y%T=80%W=0%S=Z%A=S+%F=AR%O=%RD=0%Q=)U1(R=Y%DF=N%T

OS:Z)

Network Distance: 2 hops

OS detection performed. Please report any incorrect results at https://nmap.org/submit/ .
Nmap done: 1 IP address (1 host up) scanned in 10.88 seconds

Target Identification

1. Scan All Ports

nmap -p- --min-rate 10000 -oA ./nmap-tcp <TARGET>

2. Filter Opened Ports

PORTS=$(cat nmap-tcp.nmap | grep -Eo "^[0-9]+" | tr '\n' ',' | sed -r 's/,$//')

3. Service/Script Scan

nmap -p $PORTS -sCV -oA ./nmap-tcp-scripts <TARGET>

1. Scan Default UDP Ports

nmap -sU --min-rate 10000 -oA ./nmap-udp <TARGET>

2. Filter Opened/Filtered Ports

PORTS=$(cat nmap-udp.nmap | grep -Eo "^[0-9]+" | tr '\n' ',' | sed -r 's/,$//')

3. Service/Script Scan

nmap -p $PORTS -sU -sCV -oA ./nmap-udp-scripts <TARGET>

Update Scripts Database

nmap --script-updatedb

Search Scripts

nmap --script-help <KEYWORD>*

nmap --script-help ftp*

Scan with Script

nmap --script=<SCRIPT> -sV -sC -p <PORT> <TARGET>

nmap --script=ftp-anon -sV -sC -p 21 192.168.1.1

Scan with Script Wildcard

nmap --script=<KEYWORD>* -sV -sC -p <PORT> <TARGET>

nmap --script=smb-vuln* -sV -sC -p 445 192.168.1.1

Run Script with Arguments

nmap --script=<SCRIPT> --script-args='<ARG>' -p <PORT> <TARGET>

1. Scan Common Ports

proxychains4 -q nmap -sCV -sT -Pn --unprivileged <TARGET>

item.title: Oracle Database
item.description:
Tools

# Installation
sudo apt install oracle-instantclient-sqlplus

# export LD_LIBRARY_PATH
export LD_LIBRARY_PATH=/usr/lib/oracle/19.6/client64/lib${LD_LIBRARY_PATH:+:$LD_LIBRARY_PATH}

# Check
sqlplus -V

# Installation
sudo apt install odat

# Check
odat --version

Ref: Download ODAT

Enum

# SID enum (You only need one)
odat sidguesser -s <TARGET>

item.title: POP3
item.description:
General

# Connect to POP3 mail server
telnet <TARGET> 110

# Connect with SSL
openssl s_client -connect <TARGET>:995 -crlf -quiet

# Send cmd after +OK
USER <USER>

PASS <PASSWORD>

# List all mails
LIST

# Retrieve mail #1
RETR 1

# Exit Ctrl + ], then
quit

item.title: RPC
item.description:
Remote Procedure Call

Tools

# Anonymous
rpcclient -U '' -N <TARGET>

$ rpcclient -U '' -N 10.10.10.172
rpcclient $>

# Password
rpcclient -U '<DOMAIN>/<USER>%<PASSWORD>' <TARGET>

# NTLM
rpcclient -U '<DOMAIN>/<USER>%<HASH>' --pw-nt-hash <TARGET>

# Inline Execute Command
rpcclient -U '<DOMAIN>/<USER>%<PASSWORD>' <TARGET> -c 'querydispinfo'

Basic Commands

# General info
querydispinfo

rpcclient $> querydispinfo
index: 0xfb6 RID: 0x450 acb: 0x00000210 Account: AAD_987d7f2f57d2       Name: AAD_987d7f2f57d2  Desc: Service account for the Synchronization Service with installation identifier 05c97990-7587-4a3d-b312-309adfc172d9 running on computer MONTEVERDE.

index: 0xfc3 RID: 0x641 acb: 0x00000210 Account: mhope  Name: Mike Hope Desc: (null)
index: 0xfd1 RID: 0xa36 acb: 0x00000210 Account: roleary        Name: Ray O'Leary       Desc: (null)

lookupnames <USER>

impacket-lookupsid '<USER>:<PASSWORD>@<TARGET>'

item.title: Rsync
item.description:
General

# List root directories ('/')
rsync --list-only -av rsync://<TARGET>/

$ rsync --list-only -av rsync://10.10.64.45/            
httpd           web backup

# List root directories ('/') with ipv6
rsync --list-only -av rsync://[<TARGET_IPV6>]:8730/

# List sub-directories
rsync --list-only -av rsync://<TARGET>/<DIR>/

item.title: SMTP
item.description:
Simple Mail Debugging Server

#!/usr/bin/env python3

import aiosmtpd.controller

class CustomSMTPHandler:
    async def handle_DATA(self, server, session, envelope):
        print(f"[+] Received a mail.")
        print("=" * 50)
        print(envelope.content.decode())
        print("=" * 50)
        return "250 OK"

handler = CustomSMTPHandler()
server = aiosmtpd.controller.Controller(handler, hostname="0.0.0.0", port=25)
server.start()
print("[*] Listening on 0.0.0.0:25")
input("[*] Server started. Press Return to quit.\n")
server.stop()

nmap -p 25 --script=smtp-enum-users <TARGET>

item.description:
Time Roasting

# Password

# Kerberos
sudo ntpdate -s <DC_IP> && nxc smb <DC> -u '<USER>' -p '<PASSWORD>' -k -d <DOMAIN> -M timeroast

Hash Crack

# Modified to Use rockyou.txt
python3 timecrack.py <HASH_FILE> /usr/share/wordlists/rockyou.txt


#!/usr/bin/env python3

"""Perform a simple dictionary attack against the output of timeroast.py. Neccessary because the NTP 'hash' format 
unfortunately does not fit into Hashcat or John right now.

Not even remotely optimized, but still useful for cracking legacy default passwords (where the password is the computer 
name) or specific default passwords that are popular in an organisation.
"""

from binascii import hexlify, unhexlify
from argparse import ArgumentParser, FileType, RawDescriptionHelpFormatter
from typing import TextIO, Generator, Tuple
import hashlib, sys, re

HASH_FORMAT = r'^(?P<rid>\d+):\$sntp-ms\$(?P<hashval>[0-9a-f]{32})\$(?P<salt>[0-9a-f]{96})$'

def md4(data : bytes) -> bytes:
  try:
    return hashlib.new('md4', data).digest()
  except ValueError:
    # Use pure-Python implementation by James Seo in case local OpenSSL does not support MD4.
    from md4 import MD4
    return MD4(data).bytes()

def compute_hash(password : str, salt : bytes) -> bytes:
  """Compute a legacy NTP authenticator 'hash'."""
  return hashlib.md5(md4(password.encode('utf-16le')) + salt).digest()
    

def try_crack(hashfile : TextIO, dictfile : TextIO) -> Generator[Tuple[int, str], None, None]:
  # Try each dictionary entry for each hash. dictfile is read iteratively while hashes are stored in RAM.
  hashes = []
  for line in hashfile:
    line = line.strip()
    if line:
      m = re.match(HASH_FORMAT, line)
      if not m:
        print(f'ERROR: invalid hash format: {line}', file=sys.stderr)
        sys.exit(1)
      rid, hashval, salt = m.group('rid', 'hashval', 'salt')
      hashes.append((int(rid), unhexlify(hashval), unhexlify(salt)))
  
  for password in dictfile:
    password = password.strip().decode(errors='ignore')
    for rid, hashval, salt in hashes:
      if compute_hash(password, salt) == hashval:
        yield rid, password

def main():
  argparser = ArgumentParser(formatter_class=RawDescriptionHelpFormatter, description=\
"""Perform a simple dictionary attack against the output of timeroast.py.

Not even remotely optimized, but still useful for cracking legacy default 
passwords (where the password is the computer name) or specific default 
passwords that are popular in an organisation.
""")

  argparser.add_argument('hashes', type=FileType('r'), help='Output of timeroast.py')
  argparser.add_argument('dictionary', type=FileType('rb'), help='Line-delimited password dictionary')
  args = argparser.parse_args()

  crackcount = 0
  for rid, password in try_crack(args.hashes, args.dictionary):
    print(f'[+] Cracked RID {rid} password: {password}')
    crackcount += 1

  print(f'\n{crackcount} passwords recovered.')

if __name__ == '__main__':
  main()

Ref: Timeroast
